articleContent.title: Chord: Minor b6th in A (Shape: E)
articleContent.content:
# Chord: Minor b6th in A (Shape: E)

## Overview
The Minor b6th chord in the key of A is formed by taking the notes A, C, E, and F. In this chord, the sixth (F#) is flattened to become an F note, thus giving it the Minor b6th quality. This chord can bring a unique and somewhat mysterious tension to a musical piece, often used in jazz, blues, and some forms of rock music.

## Notes and Intervals
- A (Root)
- C (Minor 3rd)
- E (Perfect 5th)
- F (Flattened 6th)

## Musical Flavor
The Minor b6th chord in A can evoke a sense of unresolved melancholy or intrigue due to the presence of the flattened 6th interval. It adds a touch of dissonance and can create a mood that is darker or more complex than traditional major or minor chords. This chord can be utilized to add depth and emotion to a musical composition.

## Songs
Here are three songs that feature the Minor b6th chord in A:
1. "Voodoo Child (Slight Return)" by Jimi Hendrix
2. "Nobody Knows You When You're Down and Out" by Bessie Smith
3. "Time of the Season" by The Zombies
